text: hello my name is Diego Hernandez I am a
technical account manager in Canada
today I will demonstrate how to use AWS
verified access policy assistant to
write access
policies using policy assistant you can
write troubl sheet and simulate policies
on the verified access console this
allows you to see how a new or modified
policy impacts your user's ability to
access
applications before we begin a quick
overview of AWS verified access verified
access is a step forward in allowing
secure access to corporate applications
hoisted on AWS over the internet in
traditional deployments access to
corporate application is delivered
through a VPN
connection in some instances this may
require traffic to Transit through an
on-prem location adding latency to the
connection verified access allows secure
access to an application over the
internet without requiring a VPN
verified access follows the zot trust
principles by granting access to
Applications is only when a user's
identity and device meet the configured
conditions as defined by a
policy verified access policies are
written in the theer language the
policies allow you to Define rules for
accessing your application hosted in AWS
the policies are evaluated against the
trust context sent from the Identity or
device-based trust providers that you
configured to use with verified
access in this demo I will show you a
use case where policy assistant can be
used to fine tune access policies faster
in this fictional scenario an
organization has rolled out a device
inpoint agent as part of the
organization's mandate to move to Zer
trust the organization will B in to
control access to corporate applications
using the device trust context data from
the newly deployed agent we will walk
through how to teste additional policy
conditions on the existing production
policy prior to pushing the update to
production
this demonstration will show you how to
F tune an existing policy the same steps
can be followed to troubleshoot and
remediate user
access before using policy assistant we
will make sure include trust context and
deliver to cloudwatch logs are enabled
on the verified access instance to do so
navigate to the PPC
view on the left hand side scroll down
to AWS verified access and click on
verified access
instances with a verified access
instance selected click on instance
loging
configuration as seen on screen
delivered to cloudwatch logs is
enabled and Trust context is
included the trust context and the
cloudwatch logs are required as policy
assistant retrieves the latest log for a
given user the trust context includes
the trust data from the authenticating
trust provider this information is used
to to validate the user meets the access
criteria as defined by the access
policy next click on the verified access
sance
ID on the top right corner launch policy
assistant here we will enter the email
address of a user and select the
associated access
inpo click
next the user I entered has not accessed
the application before policy assistant
requires the email address of a user who
recently attempted to log in this is
required for policy assistant to
retrieve the context data from the
corresponding cloudwatch log as seen on
screen an error is returned informing us
that no logs were found without logs we
cannot proceed with policy assistant
I'll now return to the previous screen
and enter the email address of a user
who has accessed the application
recently click
next policy assistant retrieves the
context data for the latest
authorization entry from the logs it
also retrieves the group and inro
policies with this you can begin to
modify the policies in the playground
without affecting the production iterate
until you get the desired
result I've prepared in new policy
condition that will assess the devices
trust context data as displayed in the
logs I will now paste the changes to the
existing policy and test the results
policy assistant has resisted the trust
data from the displayed log against the
conditions in the updated policy in this
example policy assistant validated that
the user continues to have access to the
application with the updated
policy
once you have the target policy
validated you can either cancel and make
the changes at a later time or you can
push the changes to
production click
next here we review the differences
between the existing and new policies
before applying the
changes lastly press the apply changes
button to update the existing policy as
shown on
screen policy assist has now made the
changes to the production
policy we will now verify the
corresponding access group has been
updated to the new policy to do so on
the left hand pen scroll down to
verified
access click on verified access
groups with the verified access group
selected click on
policy I shown on screen the policy has
been updated by policy
assistant
that concludes the demonstration with
policy assistant you can taste changes
to production policies using real logs
this allows faster policy development
without trial and error in
production
